post.author: bpanjavan
post.title: Certifications. What’s the point?
post.content:
Certifications.  What’s the point?  I hear a lot of strong anti-arguments that to a great extent, certifications are pointless. 

-        There exist countless developers in a company that don’t have certifications.  These are program analysts and veterans.  My own father is an incredibly well respected program analyst for Mary Kay, and any co-worker or manager couldn’t care less what his certifications are.

-        Certifications are tests.  Passing a test != (does not equal) real world experience.  As an example of a real world scenario, say our certified developer gets the problem: “Users are not getting their emails properly in QA.  Perhaps you need to debug your code against the SMTP server”.  This person may panic and say “Gee, I don’t remember this question on the test.”

-        Pass or fail, a person won’t put their score on their resume (if they even remember it…).  So one qualified person could have gotten a 930 after taking it once, while Joe Minimumachiever could have taken it 100 times and gotten a 710 on that last try.  Never mind that his average score is 200 +- 50 (a little probability analysis assuming the average question has 5 choices).

That said I’m now ready to present my argument FOR certifications.  By the way I will now address the reader of this article as a recruiter searching for candidates going forward.

 

The first anti-certification argument centers on the point of view of the senior developer / the program analyst / the veteran.  Experience and accumulated knowledge, wisdom, and most importantly, respect regarding the topic in question far outweigh any general MCPD / MCTS that someone could have.  For example say you ask “Do you have any SharePoint certifications?”.  The candidate’s response: “No, but I was the administrator for Microsoft’s public SharePoint site.”  This person clearly does not need a certification.  I acknowledge and agree.  This narrows the audience of certifications, but does NOT make them useless.

On to the second argument.  Yes, certifications are tests, and not real world experience.  But tests are NOT meaningless.  ANY top level training program puts their recruits through a test.  Ex: Boot camp, fire fighting, MCAT, etc.  No, these tests aren’t real world experience, but they’re made to be pretty darn close.  Not that we look into it, but you’ll rarely hear of a soldier who ranked top in boot camp and completely flailed on the battlefield.  Microsoft Certifications do test knowledge and judgment.  They are made to be as accurate as possible.  The candidate obviously acquired that knowledge somehow, and it’s perfectly legal to question how!  Ask him, “What did it take to pass this certification?”.  His answer will be critical and it’s guaranteed to tell you a lot about his character.

The last point is a little hard to argue against, but it also presents an extremely rare case.  Would someone seriously shell out $125 again and again without seriously trying to improve upon himself each time?  Even then, Microsoft has policies in place to prevent “certification spam”.  I believe the rule is that you have to wait 2 weeks after failing the 2nd try.  At bare minimum the candidate who failed 10 times before passing had perseverance.  He sought resources, and did what it took to pass that exam.

 

Finally, I present to you a personal case study.  You may have guessed by now this little monologue came about as a result of my own experience in obtaining Microsoft Certifications.  At Sogeti, our consultants are practically required to keep up (or catch up) with their certifications.  When I graduated college, this was pounded into my head as vital; especially because I couldn’t tell my client I had previous success stories.  Remember the first argument?  That’s not going to apply to me for at least another 10 years because I need a lot of experience for that.  Remember the 2nd argument?  I want you to look at my resume and ask “so how did you obtain this MCTS?”.  I’ll tell you that it didn’t just come to me in a dream.  I had to be proactive.  I had to explore the framework, and learn to deploy and configure a web application.  My company allowed me to spend 8 hours a day MINIMUM studying for it.  I shot for a goal and by being driven, I achieved it.  Those qualities will (and they did) help to make my first couple of client engagements a success.  Remember the third argument?  No, I don’t have the money to shell out taking 10 exams on my dime.  Yes, my company does help me pay for those certifications, but they’re not dumb.  Each time I have failed an exam I went straight to my counselor / manager to own up a full explanation of my weak points, what I would study to improve, and when I would retake.

 

In conclusion, certifications help younger developers far more than veterans.  But even for experienced developers, a certification will be very helpful if obtained in a new or unfamiliar topic.  I know a senior developer studying for a SharePoint test, because SharePoint (MOSS 2007) is relatively new, and not only is it good resume fodder, but it gives him something to shoot for and helps provide focus on the most important topics.

 

Certifications have values.  I’ve seen people who devote their time and effort into keeping up with their credentials.  I’ve seen people “look into them” and brush them off.  There is a clear difference and it goes as deep as the core of their character and in turn the type of developer they will become.

comment.content: I spent a lot of time with those butts out there in the car park, analyzing how they got there and who was responsible. A lot of the butts were where you would expect them, in the ash trays on the tables and ash trays around the front of the building. In the bins came second an equally good choice. However third came on the floor around the tables within a six foot radius of the ash trays and bins. Fourth came the grassy areas and bushes within twelve feet of the trays and bins, fifth the car park floor around the front of the building. It then seemed to fan out and get to be around all other cars parked in the car park fairly close to the building. I tried to analyze brands,styles, amount left, connect the makes with the style of cars or owner, for instance Marlborough equaled F250 or truck, all menthol could be a Prius hybrid, camel could be a recovering narcotic as they are so strong it's an attempt to get a buzz off a cigarette. The cigars were matched with the more exotic BMW, Porsche, Jag, Rolls or the like.

comment.author: &amp;#1511;&amp;#1493;&amp;#1512;&amp;#1505; &amp;#1513;&amp;#1493;&amp;#1511; &amp;#1492;&amp;#1492;&amp;#1493;&amp;#1503;
comment.content: 10 regular smokers were selected for the study. They were given a cycle each and asked to pedal at moderate speed, after they were abstained from nicotine intake for 15 hours. Then they were given FMRI (which refers to Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scans as they were shown 60 images. Among those pictures were some showing cigarettes to stimulate the craving in smokers. The next study was done on the same 10 people. They were given the same FMRI scan and the same photos were shown to them again. The brain images that were captured during both the studies show a substantial difference. In the second scan reports, patients display signs that indicated they craved for a smoke.
